comment: It's mate in 3. White cannot prevent both ...Rh8+ and h1=R+. He can only stop one of those moves from mating (if for example he plays 61.Qa1) thereafter the other move will give mate. 61.Qg3 Rxg3 62.Kh4 Rdg8 63.Kh5 and I have a choice between h1=R+mate and Rh3+mate and Rh8+mate. Alternatively he could play 61.Qe6 7 or 8 check, but this only prolongs the game for one more move and it's still mate on the next move, hence Graham's resignation.

reformulated:
Black has delivered mate in three moves. White is unable to prevent both the rook sacrifice (Rh8+) and the pawn promotion to a rook (h1=R+). If White tries to stop one, the other will still result in mate. For example, after 61.Qa1, Black responds with 61...Rxg3, then 62.Kh4, and finally 63.Kh5, with Black having a choice among Rh3+, Rdg8, or Rh8+ to deliver mate.

Alternatively, White could play 61.Qe6, but this merely extends the game by one move, with mate still arriving on the subsequent move. Therefore, Graham resigns, as there's no realistic way to defend against the imminent mate.
